Murder Machines

316 words written on Mon, May 4 2015

By the end of the 1920s, more than 200,000 Americans had been killed by automobiles. Most of these fatalities were pedestrians in cities, and the majority of these were children. ‚ÄúIf a kid is hit in a street in 2014, I think our first reaction would be to ask, ‚ÄòWhat parent is so neglectful that they let their child play in the street?,‚Äô‚Äù says Norton.

In 1914, it was pretty much the opposite. It was more like, ‚ÄòWhat evil bastard would drive their speeding car where a kid might be playing?‚Äô That tells us how much our outlook on the public street has changed‚Äîblaming the driver was really automatic then. It didn‚Äôt help if they said something like, ‚ÄòThe kid darted out into the street!,‚Äô because the answer would‚Äôve been, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs what kids do. By choosing to operate this dangerous machine, it‚Äôs your job to watch out for others.‚Äô It would be like if you drove a motorcycle in a hallway today and hit somebody‚Äîyou couldn‚Äôt say, ‚ÄòOh, well, they just jumped out in front of me,‚Äô because the response would be that you shouldn‚Äôt operate a motorcycle in a hallway.‚Äù

In the face of this traffic fatality epidemic, there was a fierce public outcry including enormous rallies, public memorials, vehement newspaper editorials, and even a few angry mobs that attacked motorists following a collision. ‚ÄúSeveral cities installed public memorials to the children hit by cars that looked like war monuments, except that they were temporary,‚Äù says Norton. ‚ÄúTo me, that says a lot, because you collectively memorialize people who are considered a public loss. Soldiers killed in battle are mourned by the whole community, and they were doing that for children killed in traffic, which really captures how much the street was considered a public space. People killed in it were losses to the whole community.‚Äù
